security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown files with API design guidance, templates, and best practices. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access beyond reading its own documentation files. All static findings are false positives: markdown code block delimiters were misidentified as shell backticks, example URLs flagged as hardcoded URLs are non-sensitive placeholders, JWT references flagged as weak cryptography are standard API authentication patterns, and HTTP method documentation was misidentified as system reconnaissance.

content.user_title: Design REST and GraphQL APIs with best practices
content.value_statement: Creating APIs without clear design patterns leads to inconsistent endpoints and poor developer experience. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for designing REST and GraphQL APIs with standardized endpoints, proper error handling, versioning strategies, and OpenAPI documentation templates.
actual_capabilities: Design RESTful API endpoints using resource-based URL patterns
Define proper HTTP status codes and response formats
Implement API versioning via URL paths or headers
Create GraphQL schemas with queries, mutations, and types
Apply security and rate limiting best practices
limitations: Does not generate implementation code for API backends
Does not validate external API specifications
Does not integrate with API gateways or testing tools
Does not execute or deploy APIs

prompt_templates.title: GraphQL schema
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a GraphQL schema for an e-commerce app with products, orders, and user types

prompt_templates.title: OpenAPI documentation

prompt_templates.title: Error handling design
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a comprehensive error handling strategy for a REST API including status codes and error response formats

output_examples.input: Design a REST API for a task management app
output: Endpoints: GET /tasks, POST /tasks, GET /tasks/:id, PATCH /tasks/:id, DELETE /tasks/:id
Response format includes data wrapper with requestId for tracing
Error responses contain code, message, and field-level details
Rate limiting headers: X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, Retry-After

output_examples.input: Create a GraphQL schema for a blog
output: Query type with posts, post, and author fields
Mutation type with createPost and addComment operations
Post type with id, title, content, author, and comments fields
Pagination support via first and after arguments
Input types for creating posts and adding comments

output_examples.input: Design authentication patterns for my API
output: Both schemes defined in OpenAPI components securitySchemes
Apply security requirements at spec level or per endpoint

best_practices: Use nouns, not verbs, in endpoint URLs for REST APIs
Apply consistent response envelopes across all endpoints
Include pagination and filtering parameters for list endpoints
Document all authentication requirements in OpenAPI specs
anti_patterns: Using verbs in URLs like /getUsers or /createPost
Returning different response formats for success vs error
Exposing sensitive data in URL parameters
Skipping versioning and breaking changes without notice

faq.question: Does this skill generate code?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides API design guidance, templates, and best practices. It does not generate implementation code.

faq.question: What API styles are supported?
faq.answer: REST and GraphQL patterns are covered with endpoints, schemas, mutations, and query patterns.

faq.question: Can it validate my existing API spec?
faq.answer: The skill provides validation checklists but does not execute against external specifications.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a prompt-based skill that reads only its own documentation files. No data leaves your session.

faq.question: What OpenAPI version is supported?
faq.answer: OpenAPI 3.0.3 specification templates are provided with full component and schema examples.

faq.question: How is this different from code generation tools?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on API design and contract definition rather than writing backend or frontend code.
